Energy-Efficient Resource Management for Federated Edge Learning with CPU-GPU Heterogeneous Computing

Qunsong Zeng, Yuqing Du, Kaibin Huang, and Kin K. Leung Q. Zeng, Y. Du, and K. Huang are with The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong. K. K. Leung is with Imperial College London, UK. Contact: K. Huang (huangkb@eee.hku.hk).
Abstract

Edge machine learning involves the deployment of learning algorithms at the network edge to leverage massive distributed data and computation resources to train artificial intelligence (AI) models. Among others, the framework of federated edge learning (FEEL) is popular for its data-privacy preservation. FEEL coordinates global model training at an edge server and local model training at edge devices that are connected by wireless links. This work contributes to the energy-efficient implementation of FEEL in wireless networks by designing joint computation-and-communication resource management (C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM). The design targets the state-of-the-art heterogeneous mobile architecture where parallel computing using both a CPU and a GPU, called heterogeneous computing, can significantly improve both the performance and energy efficiency. To minimize the sum energy consumption of devices, we propose a novel C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM framework featuring multi-dimensional control including bandwidth allocation, CPU-GPU workload partitioning and speed scaling at each device, and C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division for each link. The key component of the framework is a set of equilibriums in energy rates with respect to different control variables that are proved to exist among devices or between processing units at each device. The results are applied to designing efficient algorithms for computing the optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM policies faster than the standard optimization tools. Based on the equilibriums, we further design energy-efficient schemes for device scheduling and greedy spectrum sharing that scavenges “spectrum holes” resulting from heterogeneous C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time divisions among devices. Using a real dataset, experiments are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM on improving the energy efficiency of a FEEL system.

I Introduction

Realizing the vision of exploiting the enormous data distributed at edge devices (e.g., smartphones and sensors) to train artificial intelligence (AI) models has been pushing machine learning from the cloud to the network edge, called edge learning [1]. Currently, arguably the most popular edge learning framework is federated learning that preserves users’ privacy by distributed learning over devices [2, 3, 4]. Each round of the iterative learning process involves the broadcasting of a global model to devices, their uploading of local model updates computed using local datasets, and a server’s aggregation of the received local updates for updating the global model. Executing complex learning tasks on energy and resource constrained devices is a main challenge faced in the implementation of edge learning. To tackle the challenge, the next-generation mobile systems-on-chip (SoC) will feature a heterogeneous architecture comprising a central processing unit (CPU) and a graphics processing unit (GPU) [and even a digital processing unit (DSP) in some designs] [5]. Experiments have demonstrated its advantages in terms of performance and energy efficiency. In this work, we address the issue of energy-efficient implementation of federated edge learning (FEEL) in a wireless system comprising next-generation devices capable of heterogeneous computing. To this end, a novel framework is proposed for energy-efficient joint management of computation-and-communication (C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}) resources at devices.

I-A Edge Implementation of Federated Learning

The implementation of FEEL in wireless networks faces two key challenges among others. As mentioned, the distributed learning process requires potentially many edge devices to periodically upload high-dimensional local model updates to an edge server. This includes the first challenge that the excessive communication overhead generated in the learning process can overwhelm the air interface that has finite radio resources but needs to support FEEL as well as other services. Designing techniques for suppressing the overhead forms a vein of active research, called communication-efficient FEEL. Diversified approaches have been proposed such as device scheduling [6, 7], designing customized multi-access technologies [2, 3], and optimizing uploading frequencies [4].

The second challenge faced by FEEL is how to execute power hungry learning tasks (e.g., training AI models each typically comprising millions of parameters) on energy constrained devices. Tackling the challenge by designing energy-efficient techniques leads to the emergence of an active research theme, called energy-efficient FEEL, which is the topic of current investigation. While there exists a rich literature of energy-efficient techniques for resource management (RM) in radio access networks (see e.g., [8]), the designs of their counterparts for FEEL, which are the main research focus in energy-efficient FEEL, are different due to the changes on the system objective and operations. In particular, FEEL systems aim at improving the learning performance instead of providing a radio access service and performing update aggregation instead of decoupling multiuser data. In early works [9, 10, 11], researchers proposed radio-RM techniques (e.g., bandwidth allocation and device scheduling) to improve the tradeoff between devices’ transmission energy consumption and learning performance. More recent research accounts for computation energy consumption which usually constitutes a substantial part of a device’s total consumption in the learning process, motivating the design of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM techniques in [12, 13, 14]. In [12], the tradeoffs between learning performance (in terms of accuracy and latency) and devices’ energy consumption are optimized by balancing the communication and computation latencies under a total latency constraint, referred hereafter as C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division. In a standard FEEL design such as that in [12], the updates by devices are usually assumed synchronized. It arises from the operation of gradient aggregation and refer to the requirement that all local updates need to be received by the server before the global model can be updated. Consequently, all devices are allowed the same duration (per-round latency) for uploading their local gradients and thus synchronized in update transmission. The assumption on synchronized updates is relaxed in [13] where the learning latency is measured by a weighted sum of individual devices’ heterogeneous latencies and then the learning-energy tradeoffs similar to those in [12] are optimized. On the other hand, the idea of clock frequency control, or called dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) [15], was explored in [14] for energy-efficient FEEL based on the assumption that each device has a CPU featuring DVFS. Then the C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM was optimized where the communication RM is based on either time-division multiple access (TDMA) or non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) and the computation RM is based on dynamic frequency scaling. While prior work assumes single-processor devices, CPU-GPU heterogeneous computing discussed in the sequel is a new paradigm of mobile computing supporting applications with intensive data crunching. The area of energy-efficient FEEL based on heterogeneous computing is uncharted and explored in this work.

I-B CPU-GPU Heterogeneous Computing

The mentioned next-generation heterogeneous SoC are capable of supporting diversified workloads such as communication, signal processing, inference, and learning, which arise from a wide range of new mobile applications. Examples of such chips include Snapdragon by Qualcomm, R-series by AMD, and Kirin 970 by Huawei. Via the cooperation of the CPU and GPU on the same chip for executing a single task, heterogeneous computing on such SoC fully utilizes the computation resources of both processors to optimize the computation performance and energy efficiency [16]. In particular, the new paradigm has been demonstrated by experiments to accelerate the running of deep neural networks on smartphones [17, 18]. Existing research on heterogeneous computing focuses on several main design issues including workload partitioning [5, 19, 20, 15], dynamic frequency scaling [21, 22], and memory access scheduling [23]. The first two issues are addressed in this work. Specifically, workload partitioning refers to dividing and allocating workload of a task over the integrated CPU and GPU according to the task requirements and the processors’ states (e.g., temperatures) and characteristics (e.g., speeds and energy efficiencies) so as to optimize the overall performance and efficiency [5, 19, 20, 15]. On the other hand, frequency scaling (or DVFS) previously considered for a single CPU [12, 14] becomes the more sophisticated management in heterogeneous computing due to the joint CPU-GPU control [22]. While prior work on heterogeneous computing focuses on a single device, we study the joint control of workload partitioning and DVFS in the context of a large system comprising multiple devices and furthermore explore their integration with radio-RM.

I-C Contributions

The objective of this work is not to contribute any new learning technique but to focus on C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM to facilitate the implementation of a standard FEEL technique in a wireless network. To this end, we consider a FEEL system consisting of one edge server and multiple edge devices. Its main difference from those in existing work (see e.g., [13]) is that each device is equipped with a CPU-GPU platform enabling heterogeneous computing. The design objective is to minimize the sum energy consumption at devices under a guarantee on learning performance (latency and accuracy) by jointly controlling C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM in the following four dimensions:

  • 1)

    Bandwidth allocation: Allocating bandwidths to devices for transmission of local model updates under a constraint on the total uplink bandwidth;

  • 2)

    C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division: Dividing the allowed per-round latency for the computation and communication of each device;

  • 3)

    CPU-GPU workload partitioning: Partitioning and allocating the computation workload for each device to its CPU and GPU;

  • 4)

    CPU-GPU frequency scaling: Controlling the CPU-GPU frequencies/speeds at each device.

While the RM control in the first two dimensions are considered in prior work as discussed, the other two are unique for heterogeneous computing. Their joint control over multiple devices is a challenging and open problem. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this work represents the first attempt on studying heterogeneous computing in the context of energy-efficient FEEL. The main contributions are described as follows.

  • •

    Equilibrium based C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM framework: It is mathematically proved that the control policies are optimal if and only if they achieve the following equilibriums:

    • 1)

      The CPU-GPU pair of every device has equal energy-workload rates, defined as the increase in energy consumption per additional workload for each processing unit;

    • 2)

      A similar equilibrium also exists with respect to the processing units’ computation speeds as their optimal values are proved to be proportional to the corresponding workloads.

    • 3)

      All devices have equal energy-time rates, defined as the energy rates with respect to the communication/computation latency;

    • 4)

      All devices have equal energy-bandwidth rates, defined as the energy rates with respect to the allocated bandwidth.

    The equilibriums are applied to obtaining the optimal polices for 1) computation RM, 2) communication RM, and 3) joint C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM. They are either derived in closed-form or computed using low-complexity algorithms. In particular, for low-complexity joint C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM, the problem is decomposed into one master problem for achieving the equilibrium in energy-time rates, and two sub-problems for separately achieving the two equilibriums in energy-workload rates and energy-bandwidth rates. The resultant algorithm is shown to have much lower complexity than a standard solution method such as block coordinate descent (BCD).

  • •

    C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} aware scheduling: Building on the equilibrium framework, an energy-efficient scheduling scheme is designed to select a fixed number of devices for participating in FEEL. The novelty lies in the design of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} aware scheduling metric that balances both the channel state and computation capacity of each device. Specifically, given the objective of sum energy minimization, the metric is designed to be the energy consumption of a device given the derived optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division and equal bandwidth allocation. In addition, we analyze the effect of the number of scheduled devices on model convergence.

  • •

    Greedy spectrum sharing: For the preceding designs, we assume fixed bandwidth allocation in each round of the iterative learning process. Consequently, the heterogeneous computation latencies of devices generates “spectrum holes” (unused spectrum-time blocks) that can be scavenged for further improving the energy efficiency. To this end, the scheme of greedy spectrum sharing is designed featuring a novel metric, called energy-bandwidth acceleration rate and defined as the derivative of the energy-bandwidth rate, for selecting an available device to transmit using the spectrum hole. A larger value of the metric, implies steeper energy reduction for a device when it is allocated additional bandwidth.

II Models and Metrics

Consider the FEEL system in Fig. 1 comprising a single edge server and K𝐾K edge devices, denoted by an index set 𝒦={1,⋯,K}𝒦1⋯𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,\cdots,K\}. Each iteration between local gradient uploading and global model updating is called a communication round, or round for short. It is assumed that the server has perfect knowledge of the multiuser channel gains and local computation characteristics, which can be obtained by feedback. Using this information, the server determines the energy-efficient strategies for device scheduling and C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM.

II-A Federated Learning Model

A standard federated learning technique (see e.g., [24]) is considered as follows. A global model, represented by the parameter set 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, is trained collaboratively across the edge devices by leveraging local labelled datasets. For device k𝑘k, let 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} denote the local dataset and define the local loss function as Fk​(𝐰)=1|𝒟k|​∑(𝐱j,yj)∈𝒟kℓ​(𝐰;𝐱j,yj),subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰1subscript𝒟𝑘subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝒟𝑘ℓ𝐰subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗F_{k}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}\sum_{(\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\ell(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j}), where ℓ​(𝐰;𝐱j,yj)ℓ𝐰subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗\ell(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j}) is the sample-wise loss function quantifying the prediction error of the model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} on the training sample 𝐱jsubscript𝐱𝑗\mathbf{x}_{j} with regard to its label yjsubscript𝑦𝑗y_{j}. For convenience, we assume a uniform size for local datasets: |𝒟k|≡Dsubscript𝒟𝑘𝐷|\mathcal{D}_{k}|\equiv D, for all k𝑘k. Then the global loss function on all the distributed datasets can be written as

F​(𝐰)=∑(𝐱j,yj)∈∪k𝒟kℓ​(𝐰;𝐱j,yj)|∪k𝒟k|=1K​∑k=1KFk​(𝐰).𝐹𝐰subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘ℓ𝐰subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F(\mathbf{w})=\frac{\sum_{(\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j})\in\cup_{k}\mathcal{D}_{k}}\ell(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j})}{|\cup_{k}\mathcal{D}_{k}|}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}F_{k}(\mathbf{w}). (1)

The learning process is to minimize F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}), that is, 𝐰∗=arg⁡min⁡F​(𝐰)superscript𝐰𝐹𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}=\arg\min F(\mathbf{w}). For ease of exposition, we focus on the gradient-averaging implementation while the current designs also apply to the model-averaging implementation [24]. In each round, say the i𝑖i-th round, the server broadcasts the current model 𝐰(i)superscript𝐰𝑖{\mathbf{w}}^{(i)} as well as selection indicators {ρk}subscript𝜌𝑘\{\rho_{k}\} to all edge devices, where the indicator ρk=1subscript𝜌𝑘1\rho_{k}=1 if device k𝑘k is scheduled, or 00 otherwise. Suppose M𝑀M devices are scheduled for participation in each round, denoted by an index set ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} for the i𝑖i-th round. Based on the received model 𝐰(i)superscript𝐰𝑖{\mathbf{w}}^{(i)}, each scheduled device calculates the gradient ∇Fk​(𝐰(i))∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑖\nabla F_{k}({\mathbf{w}}^{(i)}) using its local dataset. Upon completion, the local gradients are transmitted to the server for aggregation:

𝐠(i)=1M​∑k∈ℳi∇Fk​(𝐰(i))superscript𝐠𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑘subscriptℳ𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑖{\mathbf{g}}^{(i)}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{M}_{i}}\nabla F_{k}({\mathbf{w}}^{(i)}) (2)

Synchronized updates by devices are assumed. The global model is then updated by stochastic gradient descent (SGD) as 𝐰(i+1)=𝐰(i)−η​𝐠(i)superscript𝐰𝑖1superscript𝐰𝑖𝜂superscript𝐠𝑖{\mathbf{w}}^{(i+1)}={\mathbf{w}}^{(i)}-\eta{\mathbf{g}}^{(i)}, where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. The process iterates until the model converges.

II-B Model of Heterogeneous Computing

II-B1 Workload model

Adopting a standard model (see e.g., [25]), the total workload W𝑊W for a computation task is given as W=N𝖥𝖫𝖮𝖯×D𝑊subscript𝑁𝖥𝖫𝖮𝖯𝐷W=N_{\sf FLOP}\times D, where D𝐷D is the local dataset size and N𝖥𝖫𝖮𝖯subscript𝑁𝖥𝖫𝖮𝖯N_{\sf FLOP} denotes the number of floating point operations (FLOPs) needed for processing each sample. Furthermore, we define fk(c)superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑐f_{k}^{(c)} and f′k(c)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑘𝑐{f^{\prime}}_{k}^{(c)} (in cycle/s) as the clock frequency of the CPU and GPU at device k𝑘k, respectively. It follows that the computing speeds of CPU and GPU can be defined as fk=fk(c)×nksubscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑐subscript𝑛𝑘f_{k}=f_{k}^{(c)}\times n_{k} and fk′=f′k(c)×nk′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑘′f^{\prime}_{k}={f^{\prime}}_{k}^{(c)}\times n_{k}^{\prime} with nksubscript𝑛𝑘n_{k} and nk′superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑘′n_{k}^{\prime} denoting the number of CPU and GPU FLOPs per cycle, respectively.

II-B2 Workload partitioning model

For workload partitioning in local gradient computation, we consider input-sample partitioning, also known as data parallelism [26, 27]. As a result, each processor (CPU or GPU) processes a fraction of input samples. The partitioned workloads for the CPU and GPU at device k𝑘k are denoted as Wksubscript𝑊𝑘W_{k} and W′ksubscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑘{W^{\prime}}_{k} respectively, with

(Workload constraint)Wk+Wk′=W,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequence(Workload constraint)subscript𝑊𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′𝑊for-all𝑘𝒦\text{(Workload constraint)}\quad W_{k}+{W}_{k}^{\prime}=W,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (3)

Given the partitioned workloads and CPU/GPU frequencies, the local computation time for the total workload W𝑊W, denoted as t′ksubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘{t^{\prime}}_{k}, is given as

(Local computation time)tk′=max⁡{Wkfk,Wk′fk′},∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequence(Local computation time)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘′subscript𝑊𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘′for-all𝑘𝒦\text{(Local computation time)}\quad{t}_{k}^{\prime}=\max\left\{\frac{W_{k}}{f_{k}},\frac{{W}_{k}^{\prime}}{{f}_{k}^{\prime}}\right\},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (4)

Remark 1.

(CPU/GPU Computation Efficiency). The coefficient Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} (or Gksubscript𝐺𝑘G_{k}) in (5) characterizes the computation efficiency of a CPU (or GPU), defined as the rate of power growth in response to the increase of the cubed computing speeds. In practical data processing based on heterogeneous computing, the GPU tends to play a main role (with Gk<Cksubscript𝐺𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘G_{k}<C_{k}) while the CPU contributes supplementary computing resources.

II-C Multiple-Access Model

Consider the frequency-division multiple access (FDMA) for gradient uploading with the total bandwidth B𝐵B. Let Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} denote the allocated bandwidth for device k𝑘k in an arbitrary round, which is fixed throughout the round. This assumption is relaxed in Section V. Then we have the following constraint:

(Bandwidth constraint)∑k=1KBk=B.(Bandwidth constraint)superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐵𝑘𝐵\text{(Bandwidth constraint)}\quad\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}=B. (8)

Channels are assumed to be frequency non-selective. The edge server usually recruits idling devices as workers that either static or at most moving at pedestrian speeds [24]. For this reason, we adopt the model of slow block fading. To be specific, the channel gain of device k𝑘k, denoted as hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, is assumed to remain unchanged within one round but varies independently and identically (i.i.d.) over rounds. Given synchronous updates, a time constraint is set for each round:

(Latency constraint)tk′+tk≤T,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence(Latency constraint)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘′subscript𝑡𝑘𝑇for-all𝑘𝒦\text{(Latency constraint)}\quad{t}_{k}^{\prime}+t_{k}\leq T,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (9)

where tk′superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘′{t}_{k}^{\prime} and tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k} denote the time for local training/computation and gradient uploading of device k𝑘k, respectively; T𝑇T is the maximum total time for one round. A prerequisite for a scheduled device is that it can meet the above time constraint. Let PkTXsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘TXP_{k}^{\text{TX}} denote the transmission power of device k𝑘k. The achievable rate, denoted by rksubscript𝑟𝑘r_{k}, can be written as

rk=Bk​log⁡(1+PkTX​hk2N0),∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘TXsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2subscript𝑁0for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle r_{k}=B_{k}\log\left(1+\frac{P_{k}^{\text{TX}}h_{k}^{2}}{N_{0}}\right),\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (10)

where N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the spectrum density of the complex white Gaussian channel noise. Let L=|𝐠|​α𝐿𝐠𝛼L=|\mathbf{g}|\alpha denote the gradient size (in bit) with α𝛼\alpha denoting a sufficient large number of bits for quantizing each parameter with negligible distortion. Then the data rate is rk=L/tk,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟𝑘𝐿subscript𝑡𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦r_{k}=L/t_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. By combining the result and (10), the communication energy consumption of device k𝑘k per round is

Ekcmm=Bk​PkTX​tk=Bk​tk​N0hk2​(2LBk​tk−1),∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘TXsubscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript2𝐿subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘1for-all𝑘𝒦E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}=B_{k}P_{k}^{\text{TX}}t_{k}=\frac{B_{k}t_{k}N_{0}}{h_{k}^{2}}\left(2^{\frac{L}{B_{k}t_{k}}}-1\right),\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (11)

II-D Performance Metric

It is assumed that the data distributed at devices satisfy the condition for model convergence within a finite number of rounds, denoted as N𝑁N (see e.g., [29]). As implied by (10), capacity achieving codes are deployed to ensure reliable transmissions. Consequently, wireless channels have no effects on N𝑁N though they affect per-round latencies and energy consumption. The objective of energy-efficient RM is to minimize the total energy consumption of all active devices in the N𝑁N-round learning process, namely ∑i=1N∑k=1K(Ekcmp​[i]+Ekcmm​[i])superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmpdelimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmdelimited-[]𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{N}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(E_{k}^{\text{cmp}}[i]+E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}[i]\right) with Ekcmpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmpE_{k}^{\text{cmp}} and Ekcmmsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmE_{k}^{\text{cmm}} given in (7) and (11), respectively. Given block fading and the per-round latency constraint in (9), the objective can be straightforwardly proved to be equivalent to minimize the total energy consumption for each round. This is aligned with a standard approach in adaptive transmission and its proof is similar to those in the literature (see Lemma 1 in [30]) and thus omitted for brevity. It follows that for subsequent designs, it is sufficient to consider an arbitrary round and the corresponding total energy consumption, i.e., ∑k=1K(Ekcmp+Ekcmm)superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmm\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(E_{k}^{\text{cmp}}+E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}\right), as the performance metric, is called sum energy hereafter.

III Energy-Efficient C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} Resource Management

In this section, considering the case that all devices are scheduled for uploading, we study: 1) computation RM, 2) communication RM, and 3) joint C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM by analyzing and computing the optimal policies. Then, the results are applied to establishing an energy-learning tradeoff.

III-A Computation Resource Management

III-A1 Problem Formulation

The computation resources distributed at devices can be managed by controlling their workload partitioning and speed scaling to minimize the sum computation energy. The design is formulated as the following optimization problem.

(𝐏𝟏)min{Wk,fk,fk′}∑k=1K(Ck​Wk​fk2+Gk​Wk′​fk2′)s.t.Wk+W′k=W,Wk≥0,W′k≥0,∀k∈𝒦,tk′=max⁡{Wkfk,Wk′fk′},∀k∈𝒦,0≤tk′≤T′k,∀k∈𝒦.{\bf(P1)}\quad\begin{aligned} \min_{\{W_{k},f_{k},f_{k}^{\prime}\}}\quad&\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(C_{k}W_{k}f_{k}^{2}+G_{k}W_{k}^{\prime}f_{k}^{{}^{\prime}2}\right)\\ \text{s.t.}\quad\quad&W_{k}+{W^{\prime}}_{k}=W,\quad W_{k}\geq 0,\quad{W^{\prime}}_{k}\geq 0,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ &{t}_{k}^{\prime}=\max\left\{\frac{W_{k}}{f_{k}},\frac{W^{\prime}_{k}}{f_{k}^{\prime}}\right\},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ &0\leq{t}_{k}^{\prime}\leq{T^{\prime}}_{k},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}.\end{aligned}

where the three sets of constraints follow from (3), (4), and the time constraint with Tk′superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘′T_{k}^{\prime} being the allowed maximum computation time for device k𝑘k.

III-A2 Optimal Policy

The optimal policy for computation RM is derived in closed-form below.

Lemma 1.

(Speed Scaling Rule). To minimize the sum computation energy, the computation speeds of CPU and GPU, fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} and fk′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑘f^{\prime}_{k}, should be scaled by following

Wkfk=Wk′fk′,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑊𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘′for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\frac{W_{k}}{f_{k}}=\frac{W_{k}^{\prime}}{f_{k}^{\prime}},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (12)

given an arbitrary workload pair (Wk,Wk′)subscript𝑊𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′(W_{k},W_{k}^{{}^{\prime}}) with W=Wk+Wk′𝑊subscript𝑊𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′W=W_{k}+W_{k}^{\prime}.

Proof: See Appendix -D.  □□\Box

The optimal strategy of workload-proportional speed scaling in Lemma 1 is intuitive and results from equalizing CPU and GPU computation time to avoid the slower one becoming the bottleneck of local gradient computation. Then, with Lemma 1, the original Problem P1 can be rewritten as follows:

(𝐏𝟐)min{Wk,tk′}∑k=1KCk​Wk3+Gk​Wk3′tk2′s.t.Wk+Wk′=W,Wk≥0,Wk′≥0,∀k∈𝒦,0≤tk′≤Tk′,∀k∈𝒦.{\bf(P2)}\quad\begin{aligned} \min_{\{W_{k},t_{k}^{\prime}\}}\quad&\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{C_{k}W_{k}^{3}+G_{k}{W}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}3}}{{t}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}2}}\\ \text{s.t.}\quad\quad&W_{k}+{W}_{k}^{\prime}=W,\quad W_{k}\geq 0,\quad{W}_{k}^{\prime}\geq 0,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ &0\leq{t}_{k}^{\prime}\leq{T}_{k}^{\prime},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}.\end{aligned}

Next, it is found that the optimal policy achieves an equilibrium between the CPU and GPU on each device, in terms of energy-workload rate111To be mathematical rigor, we note that the notion of rate can only be defined by the derivative function. However, it can be proved that all the partial derivative functions appeared in this manuscript are equivalent to the derivative ones. Thereby, for consistency of notation, we define the rate with respect to partial derivative hereafter. .

Lemma 2.

(Energy-Workload Rate Equilibrium). Consider the energy-workload rates of CPU and GPU given as

∂EkCPU∂Wk=3​Ck​Wk2tk2′and∂EkGPU∂Wk′=3​Gk​Wk2′tk2′,∀k∈𝒦,\displaystyle\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{CPU}}}{\partial W_{k}}=\frac{3C_{k}W_{k}^{2}}{{t}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}2}}\quad\text{and}\quad\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{GPU}}}{\partial{W}_{k}^{\prime}}=\frac{3G_{k}{W}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}2}}{{t}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}2}},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (13)

where EkCPU=Ck​Wk3tk2′E_{k}^{\text{CPU}}=\frac{C_{k}W_{k}^{3}}{{t}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}2}} and EkGPU=Gk​Wk3′tk2′E_{k}^{\text{GPU}}=\frac{G_{k}{W}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}3}}{{t}_{k}^{{}^{\prime}2}} denote the computation energy of CPU and GPU, respectively. Then, the necessary and sufficient condition for optimal workload allocation is

∂EkCPU∂Wk=∂EkGPU∂Wk′,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘CPUsubscript𝑊𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘GPUsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{CPU}}}{\partial W_{k}}=\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{GPU}}}{\partial W_{k}^{\prime}},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (14)

with Wk+Wk′=Wsubscript𝑊𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′𝑊W_{k}+{W}_{k}^{\prime}=W.

Proof: See Appendix -E.  □□\Box

Furthermore, one can observe that the objective function in P2 is a non-increasing function in t′k,∀k∈𝒦subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦{t^{\prime}}_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Therefore, the optimality requires to maximize the computation time of each device, resulting in t′k∗=T′k,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑇′𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦{t^{\prime}}_{k}^{*}={T^{\prime}}_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, which is independent of the workload partitioning. Using the result as well as Lemmas 1 and 2, the optimal computation RM policy is obtained as follows.

Proposition 1.

(Optimal Computation RM). The optimal workload allocation is

(Optimal Workload Allocation)Wk∗=Gk​WCk+Gk,Wk′⁣∗=Ck​WCk+Gk,k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence(Optimal Workload Allocation)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘𝑊subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′subscript𝐶𝑘𝑊subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\text{(Optimal Workload Allocation)}\quad W_{k}^{*}=\frac{\sqrt{G_{k}}W}{\sqrt{C_{k}}+\sqrt{G_{k}}},\quad W_{k}^{\prime*}=\frac{\sqrt{C_{k}}W}{\sqrt{C_{k}}+\sqrt{G_{k}}},\quad k\in\mathcal{K}, (15)

where Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} and Gksubscript𝐺𝑘G_{k} are computation coefficients for CPU and GPU, respectively. Moreover, the optimal speed scaling for CPU and GPU is

(Optimal Speed Scaling)fk∗=Wk∗T′k,fk′⁣∗=Wk′⁣∗T′k,k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence(Optimal Speed Scaling)superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑇′𝑘formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘′superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′subscriptsuperscript𝑇′𝑘𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\text{(Optimal Speed Scaling)}\quad f_{k}^{*}=\frac{W_{k}^{*}}{{T^{\prime}}_{k}},\quad f_{k}^{\prime*}=\frac{W_{k}^{\prime*}}{{T^{\prime}}_{k}},\quad k\in\mathcal{K},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \qquad\qquad\quad\quad (16)

where Tk′superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘′T_{k}^{\prime} is the allowed maximum computation time for device k𝑘k.

Remark 2.

(Energy-Efficient CPU-GPU Heterogeneous Computing). According to Proposition 1, more workload tends to be allocated to the processor with a smaller computation coefficient indicating a higher computation efficiency (see Remark 1), thereby reducing the devices’ energy consumption.

III-B Communication Resource Management

III-B1 Problem Formulation

The total radio resources are managed by controlling bandwidth allocation and transmission time to minimize the sum transmission energy. The corresponding optimization problem can be formulated as

(𝐏𝟑)min{Bk,tk}∑k=1KBk​tk​N0hk2​(2LBk​tk−1)s.t.∑k=1KBk=B,Bk≥0,∀k∈𝒦,0≤tk≤Tk,∀k∈𝒦.𝐏𝟑subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript2𝐿subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘1s.t.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐵𝑘𝐵formulae-sequencesubscript𝐵𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦missing-subexpressionformulae-sequence0subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦{\bf(P3)}\quad\begin{aligned} \min_{\{B_{k},t_{k}\}}\quad&\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{B_{k}t_{k}N_{0}}{h_{k}^{2}}\left(2^{\frac{L}{B_{k}t_{k}}}-1\right)\\ \text{s.t.}\quad\quad&\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}=B,\quad B_{k}\geq 0,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ &0\leq t_{k}\leq T_{k},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}.\end{aligned}

The problem has a standard structure in the literature of energy-efficient communication (see e.g., [31]). It is convex and can be solved using a standard algorithm such as BCD. In the sequel, we present an alternative solution method yielding an equilibrium property that is useful for low-complexity policy computation faster than conventional methods.

III-B2 Properties of Optimal Policies

As before, the objective of Problem P3 is observed to be a non-increasing function in tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k}. Therefore, it is optimal to maximize the transmission time of each device, resulting in tk∗=Tk,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦t_{k}^{*}=T_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Next, to derive the optimal bandwidth allocation strategy, a necessary and sufficient condition is given as follows.

Lemma 3.

(Energy-Bandwidth Rate Equilibrium). The energy-bandwidth rate as defined earlier is mathematically obtained as

∂Ekcmm∂Bk=tk​N0hk2​(2LBk​tk−L​ln⁡2Bk​tk​2LBk​tk−1)<0,k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript2𝐿subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘𝐿2subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘superscript2𝐿subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘10𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}}=\frac{t_{k}N_{0}}{h_{k}^{2}}\left(2^{\frac{L}{B_{k}t_{k}}}-\frac{L\ln{2}}{B_{k}t_{k}}2^{\frac{L}{B_{k}t_{k}}}-1\right)<0,\quad k\in\mathcal{K}. (17)

The optimal bandwidth allocation equalizes the energy-bandwidth rates as

∂E1cmm∂B1=∂E2cmm∂B2=⋯=∂EKcmm∂BK=−ν∗,superscriptsubscript𝐸1cmmsubscript𝐵1superscriptsubscript𝐸2cmmsubscript𝐵2⋯superscriptsubscript𝐸𝐾cmmsubscript𝐵𝐾superscript𝜈\displaystyle\frac{\partial E_{1}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{1}}=\frac{\partial E_{2}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{2}}=\cdots=\frac{\partial E_{K}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{K}}=-\nu^{*}, (18)

where ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*} is a constant and ∑k=1KBk=Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐵𝑘𝐵\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}=B.

Proof: See Appendix -F.  □□\Box

It can be observed from the above lemma that the increase of allocated bandwidth reduces the communication energy consumption of the device. Then, the optimal communication RM policy directly follows from the energy-bandwidth rate equilibrium as stated below.

Proposition 2.

(Optimal Bandwidth Allocation). The optimal policy for bandwidth allocation is

Bk∗=L​ln⁡2Tk​[1+𝒲0​(hk2​ν∗−Tk​N0Tk​N0​e)],k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝐿2subscript𝑇𝑘delimited-[]1subscript𝒲0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript𝜈subscript𝑇𝑘subscript𝑁0subscript𝑇𝑘subscript𝑁0𝑒𝑘𝒦\displaystyle B_{k}^{*}=\frac{L\ln{2}}{T_{k}\left[1+\mathcal{W}_{0}\!\!\left(\frac{h_{k}^{2}\nu^{*}-T_{k}N_{0}}{T_{k}N_{0}e}\right)\right]},\quad k\in\mathcal{K}, (19)

where Tksubscript𝑇𝑘T_{k} is the allowed maximum transmission time for device k𝑘k; 𝒲0​(⋅)subscript𝒲0⋅\mathcal{W}_{0}(\cdot) is the Lambert W𝑊W function (principal branch) and e𝑒e is the Euler’s number.

Proposition 2 suggests that Bk∗superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k}^{*} is a non-increasing function with respect to hk2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2h_{k}^{2}. It means that more bandwidths should be allocated to devices with weaker channels for the benefit of sum communication energy reduction.

Obtaining the optimal bandwidths {Bk∗}subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑘\{B^{*}_{k}\} via (19) requires computing the optimal energy-bandwidth rate ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*} by solving the following equation:

∑k=1KL​ln⁡2Tk​[1+𝒲0​(hk2​ν∗−Tk​N0Tk​N0​e)]=B.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝐿2subscript𝑇𝑘delimited-[]1subscript𝒲0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript𝜈subscript𝑇𝑘subscript𝑁0subscript𝑇𝑘subscript𝑁0𝑒𝐵\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{L\ln{2}}{T_{k}\left[1+\mathcal{W}_{0}\!\!\left(\frac{h_{k}^{2}\nu^{*}-T_{k}N_{0}}{T_{k}N_{0}e}\right)\right]}=B. (20)

Due to the intractability of the Lambert function 𝒲0subscript𝒲0\mathcal{W}_{0} and the unknown range of ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*}, the solution cannot be found efficiently using standard methods such as Newton-Raphson method and bi-section search. An alternative method, derivative-free optimization (DFO), which requires no derivative, has too high complexity. To address this issue, a fast algorithm for policy computation is designed below.

III-B3 Optimal Policy Computation

Instead of solving ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*} and {Bk∗}subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑘\{B^{*}_{k}\} in a sequential order, the fast algorithm calculates the optimal values iteratively, comprising the following two phases.

  • •

    Phase I: (Bandwidth Optimization). Given the energy-bandwidth rate ν𝜈\nu, compute the bandwidth allocation {Bk}subscript𝐵𝑘\{B_{k}\} using (19). As ν𝜈\nu is not optimal, the computed {Bk}subscript𝐵𝑘\{B_{k}\} may not satisfy the bandwidth constraint in (8). Thus it is necessary to normalize each Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} as B~k=B∑k=1KBk​Bksubscript~𝐵𝑘𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘\widetilde{B}_{k}=\frac{B}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}}B_{k}.

  • •

    Phase II: (Energy-Bandwidth Rate Updating). Calculate the respective energy-bandwidth rates νk=−∂Ekcmm∂Bksubscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘\nu_{k}=-\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}}, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, by substituting {B~k}subscript~𝐵𝑘\{\widetilde{B}_{k}\} and {tk=Tk}subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘\{t_{k}=T_{k}\} into (17). Then, update the current energy-bandwidth rate ν𝜈\nu using {νk}subscript𝜈𝑘\{\nu_{k}\} as elaborated in the sequel.

The two phases are iterated until convergence as indicated by the energy-bandwidth rate equilibrium in (18).

A key step in the algorithm is the update rule for ν𝜈\nu in Phase II. To derive the rule, a useful property is given as follows.

Lemma 4.

    If ν(i−1)>ν∗superscript𝜈𝑖1superscript𝜈\nu^{(i-1)}>\nu^{*}, then 1) ν∗<maxk⁡{νk(i)}<ν(i−1)superscript𝜈subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑖superscript𝜈𝑖1\nu^{*}<\max\limits_{k}\{\nu_{k}^{(i)}\}<\nu^{(i-1)}, and 2) sgn​(∑k=1KBk(i)−B)=−1sgnsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑖𝐵1\text{sgn}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}^{(i)}-B\right)=-1;

where νk(i)=νk​(B~k(i))superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑖subscript𝜈𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝐵𝑘𝑖\nu_{k}^{(i)}=\nu_{k}(\widetilde{B}_{k}^{(i)}) with B~k(i)=B∑k=1KBk(i)​Bk(i)superscriptsubscript~𝐵𝑘𝑖𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑖\widetilde{B}_{k}^{(i)}=\frac{B}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}^{(i)}}B_{k}^{(i)} given Bk(i)=Bk​(ν(i−1)),∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑖subscript𝐵𝑘superscript𝜈𝑖1for-all𝑘𝒦B_{k}^{(i)}=B_{k}(\nu^{(i-1)}),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}.

Essentially, by induction, the above Lemma 4 simply implies that if the initial point ν(0)superscript𝜈0\nu^{(0)} is greater than ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*}, and the update rule adopted for ν𝜈\nu is ν(i)=maxk⁡{νk(i)}superscript𝜈𝑖subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑖\nu^{(i)}=\max\limits_{k}\{\nu_{k}^{(i)}\}, the convergence of ν𝜈\nu to the global optimal ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*} is guaranteed. This is also true for the case of ν(0)<ν∗superscript𝜈0superscript𝜈\nu^{(0)}<\nu^{*} by involving the update rule as ν(i)=mink⁡{νk(i)}superscript𝜈𝑖subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑖\nu^{(i)}=\min\limits_{k}\{\nu_{k}^{(i)}\}. It is further noted that the condition of ν(0)>ν∗superscript𝜈0superscript𝜈\nu^{(0)}>\nu^{*} or ν(0)<ν∗superscript𝜈0superscript𝜈\nu^{(0)}<\nu^{*} can be determined by calculating sgn​(∑k=1KBk(1)−B)sgnsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘1𝐵\text{sgn}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}^{(1)}-B\right), where Bk(1)=Bk​(ν(0))superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘1subscript𝐵𝑘superscript𝜈0B_{k}^{(1)}=B_{k}(\nu^{(0)}) follows from (19). In summary, we have the following update rule for ν𝜈\nu in Phase II:

Remark 3.

(Low-Complexity and Optimality). The complexity of Algorithm 1 is O​(log⁡1ε)𝑂1𝜀O(\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}) with ε𝜀\varepsilon denoting the target accuracy. For comparison, the computation of the DFO method for solving ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*} and {Bk∗}superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘\{B_{k}^{*}\} in a sequential order is O​(1ε2)𝑂1superscript𝜀2O(\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{2}}), and that of the BCD algorithm for directly solving Problem P3 is O​(Kε​log⁡1ε)𝑂𝐾𝜀1𝜀O(\frac{K}{\varepsilon}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}), which are much higher than that of Algorithm 1. Furthermore, the optimality is guaranteed by Algorithm 1 as indicated by Lemma 4.

III-C Joint C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} Resource Management

III-C1 Problem Formulation

Building on the preceding results, an energy-efficient C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM framework is designed by joint control of workload partitioning, C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division, and bandwidth allocation to minimize sum energy. The optimization problem is formulated as

(𝐏𝟒)min{Wk,tk′,Bk,tk}∑k=1K[Ck​Wk3+Gk​W′k3t′k2+Bk​tk​N0hk2​(2LBk​tk−1)]s.t.Wk+Wk′=W,Wk≥0,Wk′≥0,∀k∈𝒦,∑k=1KBk=B,Bk≥0,∀k∈𝒦,tk′+tk≤T,tk′≥0,tk≥0,∀k∈𝒦.𝐏𝟒subscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘′subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘3subscript𝐺𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑘3superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘2subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript2𝐿subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘1s.t.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑊𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′𝑊formulae-sequencesubscript𝑊𝑘0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘′0for-all𝑘𝒦missing-subexpressionformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐵𝑘𝐵formulae-sequencesubscript𝐵𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦missing-subexpressionformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘′subscript𝑡𝑘𝑇formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘′0formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦{\bf(P4)}\quad\begin{aligned} \min_{\{W_{k},{t}_{k}^{\prime},B_{k},t_{k}\}}\quad&\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left[\frac{C_{k}W_{k}^{3}+G_{k}{W^{\prime}}_{k}^{3}}{{t^{\prime}}_{k}^{2}}+\frac{B_{k}t_{k}N_{0}}{h_{k}^{2}}\left(2^{\frac{L}{B_{k}t_{k}}}-1\right)\right]\\ \text{s.t.}\quad\quad&W_{k}+{W}_{k}^{\prime}=W,\quad W_{k}\geq 0,\quad{W}_{k}^{\prime}\geq 0,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ &\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}=B,\quad B_{k}\geq 0,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ &{t}_{k}^{\prime}+t_{k}\leq T,\quad{t}_{k}^{\prime}\geq 0,\quad t_{k}\geq 0,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}.\end{aligned}

III-C2 Properties of Optimal Policy

It is shown in the sequel that a set of equilibriums exist among devices in terms of energy rates with respect to different types of control variables when C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM is optimally energy-efficient. The insights facilitate designing low-complexity policy for solving Problem P4. First, by the same argument as in Subsections A and B, the latency constraint in Problem P4 should be active for energy minimization: t′k+tk=T,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘𝑇for-all𝑘𝒦{t^{\prime}}_{k}+t_{k}=T,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. The optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division of T𝑇T has the following property.

The proof is similar to that for Lemma 2 and thus omitted for brevity. Next, one can observe that Problem P4 integrates P2 and P3 by summing their objectives and combining their constraints. Therefore, P4 is also convex and furthermore the results in Lemmas 2 and 3 hold for the current case. Then, combining Lemmas 2, 3 and 5 yields the following main result.

Theorem 1.

(Equilibrium Based C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM). The optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM policy achieves the following equilibriums:

Remark 4.

(Equalizing C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} Heterogeneity). In the process of synchronized updates, Theorem 1 suggests that energy-efficient C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM should equalize the heterogeneity in communication channels and computation efficiencies using the multi-dimensional control variables. First, the heterogeneity in multiuser channel states and CPU/GPU computation efficiencies at each device is equalized by bandwidth allocation and workload partitioning (with speed scaling) as reflected in the second and third (with fourth) equilibriums. Second, the heterogeneity in C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} speeds is equalized by adjusting the C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division according to the first equilibrium. It is worth mentioning that C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division represents a C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} tradeoff that more communication resources can compensate for the lack of computation resources and vice versa.

III-C3 Optimal Policy Computation

Though the optimal solution for Problem P4 can be obtained by finding the equilibriums in Theorem 1 numerically using the standard method of BCD, it has high complexity. To tackle this challenge, we design a more efficient algorithm as follows. First, Problem 𝐏𝟒𝐏𝟒{\bf P4} can be decomposed into one master problem and two sub-problems as follows:

  • •

    (Master Problem): The master problem is the optimization of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division. Denote Ecmp​({T~k})superscript𝐸cmpsubscript~𝑇𝑘{E}^{\text{cmp}}(\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\}) and Ecmm​({T~k})superscript𝐸cmmsubscript~𝑇𝑘{E}^{\text{cmm}}(\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\}) as the computation and communication energy, which are functions of the allowed maximum communication time {T~k}subscript~𝑇𝑘\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\} given optimized resource management strategies output by sub-problem 1 and sub-problem 2. Then, the master problem is cast as

    (𝐌𝐏)min{T~k}Ecmp​({T~k})+Ecmm​({T~k})s.t.0<T~k<T,∀k∈𝒦.𝐌𝐏subscriptsubscript~𝑇𝑘superscript𝐸cmpsubscript~𝑇𝑘superscript𝐸cmmsubscript~𝑇𝑘s.t.formulae-sequence0subscript~𝑇𝑘𝑇for-all𝑘𝒦{\bf(MP)}\quad\begin{aligned} \min_{\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\}}\quad&{E}^{\text{cmp}}(\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\})+{E}^{\text{cmm}}(\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\})\\ \text{s.t.}\quad&0<\widetilde{T}_{k}<T,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}.\end{aligned}
  • •

    (Two Sub-problems):

    • –

      (Computation RM): Problem 𝐏𝟏𝐏𝟏{\bf P1} with {Tk′=T−T~k}superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘′𝑇subscript~𝑇𝑘\{{T}_{k}^{\prime}=T-\widetilde{T}_{k}\};

    • –

      (Communication RM): Problem 𝐏𝟑𝐏𝟑{\bf P3} with {Tk=T~k}subscript𝑇𝑘subscript~𝑇𝑘\{T_{k}=\widetilde{T}_{k}\};

As Problem P4 is convex, the optimal solutions can be obtained via iterations between the master problem and two sub-problems. Each iteration comprises two steps: 1) given {T~k}subscript~𝑇𝑘\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\}, compute the optimal RM strategies by solving two sub-problems; 2) given allocated bandwidths and partitioned workloads, calculate the sub-gradient of the master problem and apply it to updating {T~k}subscript~𝑇𝑘\{\widetilde{T}_{k}\} via the gradient descent method. The two steps are iterated until convergence.

Note that the solution of one sub-problem, namely Problem P1, can be calculated directly via (15) and (16) while numerically calculation is required for solving the other sub-problem, namely Problem P3. Given the efficient Algorithm 1 developed for computing {Bk∗}subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑘\{B^{*}_{k}\}, in the sequel, we aim at further improving the efficiency by proposing a novel initialization method of ν𝜈\nu. To this end, another useful property is introduced in the following lemma.

Lemma 6.

where ξk​(Tk)=∂Ekcmm∂tk|Tksubscript𝜉𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘\xi_{k}(T_{k})=\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial t_{k}}\big{|}_{T_{k}} is the energy-communication time rate under current time division.

As the values of {ξk​(Tk)}subscript𝜉𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘\{\xi_{k}(T_{k})\} are not attainable, ν∗superscript𝜈\nu^{*} can not be solved directly. Nevertheless, we can get a good initial point for ν𝜈\nu by taking advantage of (31). To be specific, due to the fact that ξk′​(Tk′)superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘′subscriptsuperscript𝑇′𝑘\xi_{k}^{\prime}(T^{\prime}_{k}) and ξk​(Tk)subscript𝜉𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘\xi_{k}(T_{k}) converge with iterations and ξk′​(Tk′)superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘′subscriptsuperscript𝑇′𝑘\xi_{k}^{\prime}(T^{\prime}_{k}) can be calculated by solving P1 in closed-form, we propose to initialize ν𝜈\nu as

ν0:=−1B​∑k=1KTk​ξk′​(Tk′),assignsubscript𝜈01𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑇𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘′subscriptsuperscript𝑇′𝑘\nu_{0}:=-\frac{1}{B}\sum_{k=1}^{K}T_{k}\xi_{k}^{\prime}(T^{\prime}_{k}), (32)

Such initialization provides an increasingly better initial point that is closer to the optimal solution as the outer iteration proceeds. The algorithm for computing the optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM policy is summarized in Algorithm 2.

Remark 5.

(Low-Complexity Algorithm). The proposed Algorithm 2 is of low-complexity, which has complexity up to O​(K​log2⁡1ε)𝑂𝐾superscript21𝜀O(K\log^{2}\frac{1}{\varepsilon}) as compared to that of the conventional BCD method for solving 𝐏𝟒𝐏𝟒{\bf P4}, which has complexity O​(Kε​log⁡1ε)𝑂𝐾𝜀1𝜀O(\frac{K}{\varepsilon}\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}).

III-D Discussion on Energy-Learning Tradeoff

In the literature, the model convergence of federated learning is characterized by either the averaged gradient norm (see e.g., [29]) or the loss function (see e.g., [24]), as a monotone decreasing function of the number of required rounds, N𝑁N, and participating devices K𝐾K. For example, it is reported in [29] that with a properly chosen learning rate (step size), the averaged gradient norm over rounds is shown to be proportional to 1/N1𝑁1/\sqrt{N} and 1/K1𝐾1/\sqrt{K}. In existing work, the per-round latency, T𝑇T, is assumed constant and thereby can be omitted in the convergence analysis. By considering T𝑇T or N𝑁N as a function of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} sum energy, denoted as EΣsubscript𝐸ΣE_{\varSigma}, we can discuss a learning-energy tradeoff as follows.

Definition 1.

(Learning Latency). The learning latency is defined as T𝗍𝗈𝗍𝖺𝗅=N×T​(in second)subscript𝑇𝗍𝗈𝗍𝖺𝗅𝑁𝑇in secondT_{\sf total}=N\times T\leavevmode\nobreak\ (\text{in second}).

III-D1 Fixed number of participating devices, K𝐾K

This implies a fixed distributed dataset and thus fixed N𝑁N. On the other hand, it can be inferred from Lemma 5 that T𝑇T is a monotone decreasing function of EΣsubscript𝐸ΣE_{\varSigma}. Thus, the learning latency can be written as Ttotal=N×T​(EΣ)subscript𝑇total𝑁𝑇subscript𝐸ΣT_{\text{total}}=N\times T(E_{\varSigma}), which establishes the tradeoff between Ttotalsubscript𝑇totalT_{\text{total}} and EΣsubscript𝐸ΣE_{\varSigma}. Specifically, reducing EΣsubscript𝐸ΣE_{\varSigma} can result in increased learning latency, and vice versa. Based on Lemma 5, one can see that the reduction in the learning latency leads to the increment in sum energy at a rate faster than linear.

III-D2 Fixed per-round latency, T𝑇T

For this case, an energy-learning tradeoff also exists. To be specific, it can be easily shown that the number of devices that can satisfy the per-round latency constraint is a monotone increasing function of EΣsubscript𝐸ΣE_{\varSigma}. Thereby, reducing EΣsubscript𝐸ΣE_{\varSigma} can result in a reduced number of devices participating in learning. This gives rise to a larger required number of rounds for convergence due to the shrinking of distributed dataset. Thus, the learning latency can be written as Ttotal=N​(EΣ)×Tsubscript𝑇total𝑁subscript𝐸Σ𝑇T_{\text{total}}=N(E_{\varSigma})\times T with N​(EΣ)𝑁subscript𝐸ΣN(E_{\varSigma}) being a monotone decreasing function. Then the energy-learning tradeoff is one that shortening learning latency needs more energy and vice versa. Particularly, the intermediate parameter, namely the number of participating devices, controls the said tradeoff in this case. This further motivates us to explore C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} aware device scheduling in the following section.

In general, the functions T​(EΣ)𝑇subscript𝐸ΣT(E_{\varSigma}) in the first case and N​(EΣ)𝑁subscript𝐸ΣN(E_{\varSigma}) in the second case have no closed form. The analysis of their properties (e.g., scaling laws) is an interesting topic but outside the scope of this work.

IV C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} Aware Scheduling

When there are many devices providing more than sufficient data, it is desirable from the energy-efficiency perspective to select only a subset of devices for participating in model training. In this section, the scheduler design is presented and the effect of scheduling on model convergence is quantified.

IV-A Scheduler Design

The mathematical formulation of the design is similar to P4 by modifying the objective as ∑k=1Kρk​[Ck​Wk3+Gk​W′k3t′k2+Bk​tk​N0hk2​(2LBk​tk−1)]superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜌𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘3subscript𝐺𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑘3superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘2subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript2𝐿subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘1\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\rho_{k}\left[\frac{C_{k}W_{k}^{3}+G_{k}{W^{\prime}}_{k}^{3}}{{t^{\prime}}_{k}^{2}}+\frac{B_{k}t_{k}N_{0}}{h_{k}^{2}}\left(2^{\frac{L}{B_{k}t_{k}}}-1\right)\right] under the additional constraints, namely ∑k=1Kρk=M,ρk∈{0,1},∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜌𝑘𝑀formulae-sequencesubscript𝜌𝑘01for-all𝑘𝒦\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\rho_{k}=M,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \rho_{k}\in\{0,1\},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}, where {ρk}subscript𝜌𝑘\{\rho_{k}\} are the indicator variables for selecting devices. This mixed integer non-linear problem is NP-hard and classical optimal algorithms (e.g., branch and bound) have too high complexity to be practical when K𝐾K is large. To tackle this challenge, we propose a novel C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} aware scheduler design of low-complexity to minimize sum energy.

We consider the problem of selecting M𝑀M out of K𝐾K devices for FEEL. The data distribution over devices is assumed i.i.d. as commonly make in the literature (see e.g., [12]). Then with M𝑀M fixed, device scheduling has no effect on the number of rounds N𝑁N required for learning (whose dependence on M𝑀M is studied in Section B). This allows scheduling decisions to be based on the C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} states of devices, giving the name of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} aware scheduling.

The key element of the scheduler is a scheduling metric designed as follows. Based on the preceding analysis, it is desirable to select devices with good channels or/and good computation efficiencies for energy reduction. To identify such devices, we propose to first perform equal bandwidth allocation over all devices (i.e., Bk=B¯=B/K,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝐵𝑘¯𝐵𝐵𝐾for-all𝑘𝒦B_{k}=\bar{B}=B/K,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}) and then evaluate the resulting energy consumption of each device. Note that equal bandwidth allocation enables the high energy consumption of a device to indicate: 1) a poor channel, or 2) a low computation efficiency, or 3) both. Therefore, the devices’ energy consumption with equal bandwidth allocation is a suitable scheduling metric given as:

Ek=B¯​tk∗​N0hk2​(2LB¯​tk∗−1)+ak​W3(T−tk∗)2,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐸𝑘¯𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript2𝐿¯𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘1subscript𝑎𝑘superscript𝑊3superscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘2for-all𝑘𝒦E_{k}=\frac{\bar{B}t_{k}^{*}N_{0}}{h_{k}^{2}}\left(2^{\frac{L}{\bar{B}t_{k}^{*}}}-1\right)+\frac{a_{k}W^{3}}{(T-t_{k}^{*})^{2}},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (33)

where ak≜Ck​Gk(Ck+Gk)2,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequence≜subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘2for-all𝑘𝒦a_{k}\triangleq\frac{C_{k}G_{k}}{(\sqrt{C_{k}}+\sqrt{G_{k}})^{2}},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. To compute its value, the optimal transmission time tk∗subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑘t^{*}_{k} is needed given Bk=B¯≜B/Ksubscript𝐵𝑘¯𝐵≜𝐵𝐾B_{k}=\bar{B}\triangleq B/K. Based on the energy-time rate equilibrium developed in Lemma 5, tk∗superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k}^{*} solves the equation below:

f​(tk∗)=B¯​N0hk2​(2LB¯​tk∗−L​ln⁡2B¯​tk∗​2LB¯​tk∗−1)+2​ak​W3(T−tk∗)3=0.𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘¯𝐵subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2superscript2𝐿¯𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝐿2¯𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘superscript2𝐿¯𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘12subscript𝑎𝑘superscript𝑊3superscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘30f(t_{k}^{*})=\frac{\bar{B}N_{0}}{h_{k}^{2}}\left(2^{\frac{L}{\bar{B}t_{k}^{*}}}-\frac{L\ln{2}}{\bar{B}t_{k}^{*}}2^{\frac{L}{\bar{B}t_{k}^{*}}}-1\right)+\frac{2a_{k}W^{3}}{(T-t_{k}^{*})^{3}}=0. (34)

A closed-form expression for tk∗superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k}^{*} is hard to derive but can be numerically computed by a bi-section search since f​(tk∗)𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘f(t_{k}^{*}) is a monotonically increasing function. Given the values of {Ek}subscript𝐸𝑘\{E_{k}\}, the C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} aware scheduler selects M𝑀M devices with the smallest values. The scheduling scheme is summarized in Algorithm 3.

IV-B Effect of Scheduling on Convergence

In this subsection, we quantify the effect of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} aware scheduling (without considering data importance) on the convergence rate of FEEL (in round) due to the reduced size of selected dataset for model updating. For tractable analysis, we follow the standard assumptions on the loss function as made in the literature (see e.g., [4]).

Assumption 1.

It is assumed that the loss functions has the following two properties:

  • •

    (Convexity and Smoothness). All functions {Fk}subscript𝐹𝑘\{F_{k}\} are convex and β𝛽\beta-smooth, that is, for all 𝐮,𝐯𝐮𝐯\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}, we have

    ⟨∇Fk​(𝐯),𝐮−𝐯⟩≤Fk​(𝐮)−Fk​(𝐯)≤⟨∇Fk​(𝐯),𝐮−𝐯⟩+β2​‖𝐮−𝐯‖2∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐯𝐮𝐯subscript𝐹𝑘𝐮subscript𝐹𝑘𝐯∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐯𝐮𝐯𝛽2superscriptnorm𝐮𝐯2\displaystyle\langle\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{v}),\mathbf{u}-\mathbf{v}\rangle\leq F_{k}(\mathbf{u})-F_{k}(\mathbf{v})\leq\langle\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{v}),\mathbf{u}-\mathbf{v}\rangle+\frac{\beta}{2}\|\mathbf{u}-\mathbf{v}\|^{2} (35)
  • •

    (Variance Bound). Stochastic gradients {∇Fk​(𝐰)}∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\{\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\} are unbiased and variance bounded by σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, that is,

    𝔼​[∇Fk​(𝐰)]=∇F​(𝐰)and𝔼​[‖∇Fk​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)‖2]≤σ2,formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰∇𝐹𝐰and𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰∇𝐹𝐰2superscript𝜎2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w})]=\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\qquad\text{and}\qquad\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}, (36)

    where ∇Fk​(𝐰)∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) and ∇F​(𝐰)∇𝐹𝐰\nabla F(\mathbf{w}) denote the gradients of a local loss function and the global loss function, respectively, and the expectations are taken over all devices.

Under the above assumptions, the upper bound on the convergence rate of FEEL algorithm with device scheduling is given in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.

(Convergence Rate with Scheduling). Given the learning rate as η=1N𝜂1𝑁\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}, the convergence rate of the FEEL algorithm with device-scheduling can be upper-bounded as

1N​∑i=0N−1𝔼ℳi​[F​(𝐰(i))−F​(𝐰∗)]≤1N​[‖𝐰(0)−𝐰∗‖2+σ2​(K−M)(K−1)​M].1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑁1subscript𝔼subscriptℳ𝑖delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑖𝐹superscript𝐰1𝑁delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2superscript𝜎2𝐾𝑀𝐾1𝑀\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=0}^{N-1}\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{M}_{i}}\left[F({\mathbf{w}}^{(i)})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\right]\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left[\|\mathbf{w}^{(0)}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\|^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}(K-M)}{(K-1)M}\right]. (37)

where N𝑁N denotes the number of communication rounds.

Proof: See Appendix -H.  □□\Box

Compared with the existing results without scheduling (see e.g., [32] and [12]), the last term in (37) is new that characterizes the effect of scheduling on learning. One can observe from the term that increasing the number of scheduled devices M𝑀M leads to the vanishment of the biased term at a rate of O​(1M)𝑂1𝑀O(\frac{1}{M}), giving rise to a faster convergence rate, however, at the cost of more sum energy consumption scales faster than linearly with M𝑀M.

V Extension: Greedy Spectrum Sharing

In the preceding sections, the bandwidths are allocated at the beginning of each round and then fixed throughout the round. However, as mentioned, the heterogeneity in the computation durations of devices may result in spectrum holes as illustrated in Fig. 2. Scavenging them by spectrum sharing among devices can reduce sum energy, which is the theme of this section.

While optimizing the spectrum sharing is intractable, we design a practical scheme based on the greedy principle. The scheme allocates the spectrum hole upon its arrival to one of available devices for transmission (in addition to the pre-allocated bandwidth) so as to reduce its energy consumption, called greedy spectrum sharing. To design the scheme, we divide the round into multiple time slots. Furthermore, let 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and 𝒮ℓsubscript𝒮ℓ\mathcal{S_{\ell}} denote the sets of scheduled devices and a subset of devices that have completed computation at the beginning of a particular time slot, respectively. Then, the resulting spectrum holes have the total bandwidth of B−∑k∈𝒮ℓBk∗𝐵subscript𝑘subscript𝒮ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘B-\sum_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{\ell}}B_{k}^{*} with Bk∗superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k}^{*} denoting the pre-allocated bandwidth to device k𝑘k, which is determined at the beginning of each round. Intuitively, all the unoccupied bandwidths should be allocated to the device k∈𝒮ℓ𝑘subscript𝒮ℓk\in\mathcal{S_{\ell}} that has the largest energy reduction with respect to bandwidth growth. Mathematically, this selection metric is to select the device, denoted as k∗superscript𝑘k^{*}, with the minimum energy-bandwidth rate at Bk∗superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k}^{*} provided ∂Ekcmm∂Bk<0,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}}<0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, that is

k∗=arg⁡mink∈𝒮ℓ⁡∂Ekcmm∂Bk|Bk∗.superscript𝑘evaluated-atsubscript𝑘subscript𝒮ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘\displaystyle k^{*}=\arg\min_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{\ell}}\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}}\bigg{|}_{B_{k}^{*}}. (38)

However, according to Lemma 3, the energy-bandwidth rates of all scheduled devices are equalized at equilibrium, making this criterion ineffective. To address this issue, we design an alternative metric that can also effectively reduce sum energy. To this end, we introduce the following notion.

Definition 2.

(Acceleration Rate). The acceleration rate is defined as the partial derivative of the energy-bandwidth rate:

φk​(Bk):=∂2Ekcmm∂Bk2=2LBk​tk​L2​N0​(ln⁡2)2Bk3​tk​hk2>0,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝜑𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘superscript2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘2superscript2𝐿subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘superscript𝐿2subscript𝑁0superscript22superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘3subscript𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘20for-all𝑘𝒦\varphi_{k}(B_{k}):=\frac{\partial^{2}E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}^{2}}=\frac{2^{\frac{L}{B_{k}t_{k}}}L^{2}N_{0}(\ln 2)^{2}}{B_{k}^{3}t_{k}h_{k}^{2}}>0,\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (39)

To be mathematical rigor, we note that the notion of acceleration rate can only be defined by the second derivative. However, it can be proved that the second-order partial derivative here is equivalent to the second derivative of energy w.r.t. the allocated bandwidth (see Appendix -I). A device with a small acceleration rate implies a lower energy-bandwidth rate upon being allocated with extra bandwidths, leading to more energy reduction. Therefore, we propose to adopt the criterion of minimum acceleration rate at {Bk=Bk∗}subscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘\{B_{k}=B_{k}^{*}\}, namely {φk​(Bk∗)}subscript𝜑𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘\{\varphi_{k}(B_{k}^{*})\}, as follows

(Device Selection)k∗=arg⁡mink∈𝒮ℓ⁡φk​(Bk∗).(Device Selection)superscript𝑘subscript𝑘subscript𝒮ℓsubscript𝜑𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘\displaystyle\text{(Device Selection)}\quad k^{*}=\arg\min_{k\in\mathcal{S}_{\ell}}\varphi_{k}(B_{k}^{*}). (40)

Based on the above criterion, the scheme is summarized in Algorithm 4.

VI Experimental results

VI-A Experiment Setup

The simulation settings are as follows unless specified otherwise. In the FEEL system, there are K=50𝐾50K=50 devices and each of them is capable of CPU-GPU heterogeneous computing. The devices’ CPU and GPU coefficients, {Ck}subscript𝐶𝑘\{C_{k}\} and {Gk}subscript𝐺𝑘\{G_{k}\}, are uniformly selected from the the set {0.020,0.021,⋯,0.040}0.0200.021⋯0.040\{0.020,0.021,\cdots,0.040\} and {0.001,0.002,⋯,0.010}0.0010.002⋯0.010\{0.001,0.002,\cdots,0.010\}, respectively. Consider an FDMA system with the uplink bandwidth B=5𝐵5B=5 MHz. The channel gains {hk}subscriptℎ𝑘\{h_{k}\} are modeled as i.i.d. Rayleigh fading with average path loss set as 10−3superscript10310^{-3}. The noise variance is N0=10−9subscript𝑁0superscript109N_{0}=10^{-9} W/Hz. The classification task aims at classifying handwritten digits from the well-known MNIST dataset. Each device is randomly assigned 202020 samples. The classifier model is implemented using a 6-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) which consists of two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers with ReLU activation, each followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling, a fully connected layer with 50 units and ReLU activation, and a final softmax output layer. The total number of parameters is 21,8402184021,840 and the computation workload is W=9.75𝑊9.75W=9.75 MFLOPs. Furthermore, we suppose that each parameter of the training model gradient is quantized into 16 bits, and as a result, the transmission overhead is L=3.49×105𝐿3.49superscript105L=3.49\times 10^{5} bits.

VI-B C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} Resource Management

VI-B1 Energy-efficient RM

The performance of the proposed computation RM, communication RM and joint C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM policies are evaluated by simulations. To be specific, we consider two settings: a) uniform time division [see Fig. 3(a)]; and b) optimal time divisions [see Fig. 3(b)]. Under each setting, we consider four schemes: 1) C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM, 2) only computation RM, 3) only communication RM, and 4) without RM. In particular, to distinguish our proposed optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM policy, we name the policy with C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM under uniform time division setting as “separate C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM” while the proposed optimal one is called “joint C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM”. The curves of the sum energy versus the per-round latency T𝑇T are illustrated in Fig. 3. Serveral observations can be made. First, the sum energy reduces as T𝑇T grows for all cases. This coincides with the results in Lemma 5 that the energy consumption is a monotonically decreasing function in computation and communication time. Second, for either setting a) or b), it can be found that the two schemes 2) and 3), namely only computation RM and only communication RM, outperform the scheme without RM but underperform the C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM. For example, under setting a), they reduce the sum energy of the policy without RM by 13.8%percent13.813.8\% and 43.5%percent43.543.5\%, respectively, for per-round latency equal to 1.01.01.0 s. Meanwhile, the separate C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM scheme reduces the sum energy of the policy without RM by 57.3%percent57.357.3\%. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed workload and bandwidth allocation policies for C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM. Third, comparing the results in setting a) with b), we find that the strategy of C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division plays a significant role in energy efficiency. For example, the four schemes 1)-4) in b) with optimal time divisions reduce the sum energy of those in a) by 17.2%percent17.217.2\%, 47.5%percent47.547.5\%, 9.8%percent9.89.8\%, and 43.5%percent43.543.5\%, respectively, for per-round latency equal to 1.01.01.0 s. This coincides with Remark 4 that the optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} time division achieves the best energy efficiency by balancing C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2} heterogeneity. Fourth, our proposed joint C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM policy outperforms all other schemes, showing its effectiveness. For example, it reduces the sum energy of the schemes 1)-4) in a) by 17.2%percent17.217.2\%, 59.0%percent59.059.0\%, 37.4%percent37.437.4\%, and 64.6%percent64.664.6\%, as well as the schemes 2)-4) in b) by 21.9%percent21.921.9\%, 31.3%percent31.331.3\%, and 37.4%percent37.437.4\%, respectively, for per-round latency equal to 1.01.01.0 s.

VI-B2 Greedy spectrum sharing

The performance of the proposed greedy spectrum sharing algorithm in Algorithm 4 is benchmarked against the optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM without spectrum sharing in Algorithm 2. Note that the number of devices are set to be K=20𝐾20K=20 with high heterogeneity regarding their computation efficiencies and channels. The curves of sum energy versus the bandwidth B𝐵B are plotted in Fig. 4. Two observations can be made. First, the sum energy reduces as B𝐵B grows as more bandwidths can be traded for lower transmission power. Second, it can be found that the proposed greedy spectrum sharing policy improves the energy efficiency of the C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM without spectrum sharing by scavenging unused radio resources. For example, it reduces sum energy of the baseline scheme, namely optimal C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}RM without spectrum sharing by 10.6%percent10.610.6\% for uplink bandwidth equal to 2.52.52.5 MHz.

VI-C Device Scheduling

Consider the scenario that the edge server schedules a subset of devices for learning. The communication round number is fixed as 101010 with T=1𝑇1T=1 s for each round. The performance of the proposed C2superscriptC2\text{C}^{2}-aware scheduling is benchmarked against the random selection scheme. The effects of the number of scheduled devices M𝑀M on the average learning accuracy of the FEEL algorithm and sum energy consumption are shown in Fig. 5. Several observations can be made as follows. First, the average learning accuracy is an increasing function of M𝑀M as it increases the training data per round. Second, it can be observed that the increase on M𝑀M leads to the growth of sum energy at a rate faster than linear, which agrees with the preceding discussion. Furthermore, one can observe that the proposed scheduling scheme outperforms the baseline which randomly selects M𝑀M devices, e.g., achieving 39.8%percent39.839.8\% sum energy reduction for M=35𝑀35M=35.

-E Proof of Lemma 2

-H Proof of Theorem 2

At the beginning of the (i+1𝑖1i+1)-th round, all the devices receive the global model 𝐰(i)superscript𝐰𝑖{\mathbf{w}}^{(i)}. However, the edge server only schedules M𝑀M devices for gradient computation, which makes the problem sophisticated to solve. To tackle the challenge, we use a trick that we assume all the devices compute the gradients {∇Fk​(𝐰(i))}∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑖\{\nabla F_{k}({\mathbf{w}}^{(i)})\} based on their local datasets while only M𝑀M of them are aggregated for global model updating. 𝐰(i+1)=𝐰(i)−ηM​∑k∈ℳi∇Fk​(𝐰(i))=1M​∑k∈ℳi(𝐰(i)−η​∇Fk​(𝐰(i))).superscript𝐰𝑖1superscript𝐰𝑖𝜂𝑀subscript𝑘subscriptℳ𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑘subscriptℳ𝑖superscript𝐰𝑖𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑖{\mathbf{w}}^{(i+1)}={\mathbf{w}}^{(i)}-\frac{\eta}{M}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{M}_{i}}\nabla F_{k}({\mathbf{w}}^{(i)})=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{M}_{i}}\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(i)}-\eta\nabla F_{k}({\mathbf{w}}^{(i)})\right). (49)

We define the virtual local updated model at device k𝑘k as 𝐰k(i+1)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖1\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(i+1)} and denote it as

-I Clarification of Definition 2

Since Wksubscript𝑊𝑘W_{k} and Wk′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝑘W^{\prime}_{k} are irrelevant to the allocated bandwidth Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k}, the derivative of energy with respect to bandwidth can be calculated as follows:

d​Ekd​Bk𝑑subscript𝐸𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘\displaystyle\frac{dE_{k}}{dB_{k}} =∂Ekcmm∂Bk+∂Ekcmp∂t′k​d​t′kd​Bk+∂Ekcmm∂tk​d​tkd​Bkabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmpsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}}+\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmp}}}{\partial{t^{\prime}}_{k}}\frac{d{t^{\prime}}_{k}}{dB_{k}}+\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial t_{k}}\frac{dt_{k}}{dB_{k}} (73)
=∂Ekcmm∂Bk+ξk​(d​t′kd​Bk+d​tkd​Bk)=∂Ekcmm∂Bk,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝜉𝑘𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘𝑑subscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}}+\xi_{k}\left(\frac{d{t^{\prime}}_{k}}{dB_{k}}+\frac{dt_{k}}{dB_{k}}\right)=\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}},

where the energy-time rate equilibrium (see Lemma 5) gives ∂Ekcmp∂t′k=∂Ekcmm∂tk≜ξksuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmpsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝑡𝑘≜subscript𝜉𝑘\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmp}}}{\partial{t^{\prime}}_{k}}=\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial t_{k}}\triangleq\xi_{k}, and the time constraint, namely t′k+tk=Tsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘𝑇{t^{\prime}}_{k}+t_{k}=T, gives d​t′kd​Bk+d​tkd​Bk=0𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘𝑑subscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘0\frac{d{t^{\prime}}_{k}}{dB_{k}}+\frac{dt_{k}}{dB_{k}}=0.

Then, we can derive the second derivative of energy with respect to bandwidth as follows:

d2​Ekd​Bk2superscript𝑑2subscript𝐸𝑘𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘2\displaystyle\frac{d^{2}E_{k}}{dB_{k}^{2}} =dd​Bk​∂Ekcmm∂Bk=∂2Ekcmm∂Bk2+∂2Ekcmp∂Bk​∂tk′​d​tk′d​Bk+∂2Ekcmm∂Bk​∂tk​d​tkd​Bkabsent𝑑𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘superscript2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘2superscript2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmpsubscript𝐵𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘superscript2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{d}{dB_{k}}\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}}=\frac{\partial^{2}E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}E_{k}^{\text{cmp}}}{\partial B_{k}\partial t^{\prime}_{k}}\frac{dt^{\prime}_{k}}{dB_{k}}+\frac{\partial^{2}E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}\partial t_{k}}\frac{dt_{k}}{dB_{k}} (74)
=∂2Ekcmm∂Bk2+∂∂Bk​(∂Ekcmp∂tk′−∂Ekcmm∂tk)​d​tk′d​Bk=∂2Ekcmm∂Bk2.absentsuperscript2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘2subscript𝐵𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmpsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘superscript2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘cmmsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘2\displaystyle=\frac{\partial^{2}E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}^{2}}+\frac{\partial}{\partial B_{k}}\left(\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmp}}}{\partial t^{\prime}_{k}}-\frac{\partial E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial t_{k}}\right)\frac{dt^{\prime}_{k}}{dB_{k}}=\frac{\partial^{2}E_{k}^{\text{cmm}}}{\partial B_{k}^{2}}.
